globalMetadata.title: Good Thinking - NHS approved wellbeing service
globalMetadata.description: Anxious, stressed, depressed or having trouble sleeping? Find NHS-approved mental health tools and advice to support you.

footer.description: Good Thinking provides a range of resources to help Londoners improve their mental wellbeing.

subscribeFooterText.copy: Get the latest tips and resources for Londoners delivered to your inbox every month.

partners.name: Transformation Partners in Health and Care

howToUseSection.bodyText:
Find support, advice and resources by:

  • Mental health concern

Sleep, Anxiety, Low mood, Stress.

  • Audience

Young people, Employers and employees, Someone who is grieving, Faith and belief communities.

  • Type of support

Self-assessments, free apps, podcasts, videos, how to guides, workbooks.

Get expert advice from Good Thinking

The Good Thinking team has created a broad range of advice in collaboration with clinical and subject-area experts, designed to support Londoners with everyday mental health challenges.

In our Latest Advice section, you'll find short guides with tips and resource recommendations to help you with a range of concerns including dealing with uncertainty, money worries, getting enough sleep and coping with bereavement. 

If you’re looking for advice on a specific subject, type in your topic in the ‘search﻿’ box at the top of the page.

howToUseSection.bodyText:
Use the Good Thinking self-assessment tool

Our in-depth, clinically validated self-assessments are a thorough assessment of both your mental and physical wellbeing. They may seem quite ‘medical’ because they are based on the types of questions a doctor or a psychologist might ask you.

  • Each self-assessment takes around 20 minutes to complete
  • Answer questions about yourself or someone you may be concerned about
  • You’ll get a personalised list of recommended actions to take forward

Find the right help for you

Tell us what you're looking for help with and who you're looking for help for and you’ll then receive personalised recommendations for apps and other resources to meet your needs.

adviceData.title: How to stay mentally healthy at university
adviceData.subtitle: A toolkit for students giving tips and advice to help you to stay mentally healthy and make the most of your university experience.

metadata.description: A toolkit for students giving tips and advice to help you to stay mentally healthy and make the most of your university experience.
metadata.title: How to stay mentally healthy at university

contentSections.content:
University can be an exciting time. Indeed, for many young people, it’s almost become a rite of passage – a steppingstone to learning, development and growth in the transition to adult life.

However, it’s also a time of significant change for many young people, be it moving away from home for the first time, navigating to build new ‘life’ skills or forming new friendship groups. For some, these changes can be overwhelming, and it’s perfectly normal to feel anxious, stressed or low. According to a 2022 survey by charity Student Minds, over half of respondents self-reported a mental health concern, with over a quarter stating they had a diagnosed mental health condition.

Whether you’re a fresher who has lost their confidence or a final year student who is worried about the job market, finding the right advice and guidance to support your mental wellbeing is vital. With the cost of living soaring, you might also be feeling stressed about your finances – indeed, research by the National Union of Students (NUS) in July 2022 showed that one in three students in the UK has less than £50 a month left in their pocket after paying rent and bills.

Our toolkit for students contains recommendations for free NHS-approved mental wellbeing apps, including Student Health App, Clear Fear and Combined Minds, as well as links to expert advice on a wide range of student-related topics.

We hope you find this toolkit useful and, don’t forget, you can contact your university’s wellbeing, welfare and finance services to discuss any particular concerns. You can also get in touch with Shout (text STUDENT to 85258) or Samaritans (call 116 123 or email jo@samaritans.org). If you need urgent help, you can find details of support organisations on Good Thinking’s Urgent Support page.

tabs.title: Top tips
tabs.content:
1. Stay connected – make the most of opportunities to meet new people (e.g. through clubs and societies) and have fun with your friends. Stay in touch with your family via phone calls, texts and video chat and be honest about how you’re feeling so that they can support you. You might also find it useful to join an online community, such as The Student Room, where you can share your experiences with other students.
  2. Be physically active – whether you walk, run, cycle, go to the gym or join a university sports club, being active is great for your mental wellbeing too. You might also like to try some workouts on YouTube or download a fitness app to keep you on track. If you’re doing any of your learning virtually or spending lots of time studying at a desk, make sure you schedule time for fresh air and exercise breaks.
  3. Learn something new each day – of course, you’ll be learning lots of new stuff on your course but why not see if there are any clubs or societies you could join? Art, debating, football, geology, photography, Spanish, windsurfing... there's something for everyone. You could also take this time to teach yourself a new skill, like how to cook a meal you’ve not tried before.
  4. Give to others – acts of kindness don’t only help other people, they can also give you a feeling of purpose. It can be as simple as asking a friend how they are and spending some time with them. If any of your friends are feeling anxious or stressed, you can use the free Combined Minds app to support them. You might also like to volunteer for a local charity or take part in a fundraising campaign that your university is running.
  5. Pay attention to the present moment – being aware of your thoughts and the world around you can help to improve your mental wellbeing. If you feel frustrated that your school, college or university experience is different to how you wanted it to be, you might like to download a mindfulness or meditation app.

For more information, read our five ways to good mental wellbeing article. We've also started producing wellbeing guides for different faith and belief communities – check them out here.

tabs.title: Need practical support?
tabs.content:
Going to university is very exciting but it can also be nerve-racking, especially if you’ve never lived away from home or if you have money worries. Indeed, a recent survey by The Student Room found that more than a fifth (21%) of university students say they need support for life skills (e.g. cooking, cleaning and laundry) and 16% want advice on money management.

To help you deal with the practicalities and worry less, the Good Thinking team has put together a list of links to useful websites and also created a checklist to help you decide what to pack for university and a checklist to help you deal with money worries at university .

  • Download the free Student Health App to instantly access reliable, relevant and reassuring health and wellbeing information
  • If you are a student coming to study in the UK, download the free International Student App to access info & tips that will help you to settle into university life
  • Before you go to university (The Uni Guide)
  • Best money resources for students (Save the Student)
  • Freshers Week tips from students (The Student Room)
  • Jumpstart University (various resources from The Open University and the Russell Group)
  • Money management advice for students (MoneySavingExpert)
  • Preparing for university (Student Space)
  • The ultimate guide to surviving your first week of uni (The Student Room)
  • Student Finance Zone (The Student Room)
  • University: A Freshers' survival guide (YoungMinds)

Your university's website should also contain lots of helpful information and, if you're feeling especially anxious or you have a specific support need, you can always talk to your university's wellbeing, welfare or finance service. The Student Space website contains a really useful ‘Find support at your university’ page – simply type in the name of your uni and it provides links to the services on offer.

If you're starting university for the first time, some universities are offering online chats with current students so that you can find out more about life on campus – or you might like to check out The Student Room forums.

tabs.title: Feeling anxious?
tabs.content:
You might be feeling anxious about starting at, or going back to, university. This might include how you'll keep up with your studies, manage your finances or make new friends. Good Thinking has lots of tools to help you manage any feelings of anxiety (and to support your friends if they feel the same).

  • Apps: Check out these NHS-approved apps that are free to Good Thinking users who live, study or work in London – Be Mindful, ,Meditainment, MyCognition PRO, My Possible Self and tomo. You might also find the free Clear Fear app, Feeling Good app, Student Health App, Combined Minds app and International Student App helpful.
  • Articles: Read Good Thinking’s advice about Five ways to good mental wellbeing and Mental health and me. If you're concerned about how you'll cope with your rent and bills at uni, check out our tips.
  • Podcasts: Listen to the Good Thinking podcasts about mindfulness, OCD and mental health from a male perspective.
  • Workbooks: Take a look at the Centre for Clinical Interventions workbooks on anxiety, health anxiety and mindfulness

tabs.title: Having trouble sleeping?
tabs.content:
If you’re struggling to get to sleep or waking in the night, you’re not alone – around a third of adults have trouble sleeping at some point in their lives. Rest and relaxation is really important for both your physical and mental health so Good Thinking provides a range of resources to support you in your quest for a good night’s sleep.

  • Apps: Check out these NHS-approved apps that are free to Good Thinking users who live, study or work in London – Be Mindful, Meditainment and tomo.
  • Podcast: Get advice from an NHS sleep expert in Good Thinking’s podcast about sleep.
  • Workbooks: Learn more about sleep and self-compassion in these Centre for Clinical Interventions workbooks and use the Good Thinking Sleep Workbook, which contains a six-week programme for better sleep.

tabs.title: Feeling down?
tabs.content:
Concerns about starting or being back at university might be affecting your mood. If so, there are lots of things you can do to build your resilience and help you to stay positive. The Good Thinking resources below are a good place to start.

  • Apps: Check out these NHS-approved apps that are free to Good Thinking users who live, study or work in London – Be Mindful, Meditainment, MyCognition PRO, My Possible Self and tomo. You might also find the free Clear Fear app, Feeling Good app, Student Health App and International Student App helpful. If you have recently lost a loved one and would like bereavement support, we recommend the free Apart of Me app.
  • Articles: Read Good Thinking’s advice about Five ways to good mental wellbeing and Mental health and me. If you have recently lost a loved one, you might find our articles about coping with bereavement helpful.
  • Podcasts: Listen to Good Thinking’s podcasts about coping with isolation and retaining hope.
  • Workbook: Find lots of tips and tools for managing low mood in the Centre for Clinical Interventions depression workbook, which includes Back from the Bluez modules.

tabs.title: Stressed out?
tabs.content:
Stress is a perfectly normal reaction to a threat – it prepares you for ‘fight or flight’. But if it’s affecting your daily life, Good Thinking can recommend free NHS-approved apps to help lower your stress.

  • Apps: Check out these NHS-approved apps that are free to anyone who lives, studies or works in London – Be Mindful, MyCognition PRO, My Possible Self and tomo. You might also find the free Clear Fear app, Sorted: Mental Health app, Student Health App and International Student App helpful.
  • Articles: Learn how to connect with nature to boost your wellbeing. With food, fuel and energy bills increasing, you might be feeling stressed about your finances – check out our tips.
  • Podcasts: Listen to Good Thinking’s podcasts about dealing with stress and trauma and mindfulness.
  • Workbook: Take a look at the mindfulness workbook.

tabs.title: Useful resources
tabs.content:
Other useful Good Thinking resources

  • Mental health and debt (podcast)
  • How to spot disinformation, misinformation and fake news
  • Q&A: Eating disorders
  • Supporting a healthy screen/life balance
  • Supporting those with eating disorders (podcast)


Other useful websites

  • BBC Radio 1 (Life Hacks podcasts about anxiety, careers, money, self-esteem and other wellbeing topics)
  • Beat (eating disorder charity)
  • Brook (sexual health charity)
  • Campaign Against Living Miserably (CALM) (suicide prevention charity)
  • Every Mind Matters (mental health advice)
  • Frank (drugs advice)
  • Hopeline UK - Papyrus (suicide prevention charity)
  • MindOut (mental health charity for LGBTQ community)
  • My Mind TV (videos) (click Explore, select Children and Young People, select 18+, click Apply)
  • NHS talking therapies
  • Nightline (student listening service)
  • One Space (support for under 25s)
  • Samaritans (helpline)
  • Shout (helpline)
  • Stonewall (charity for LGBT+ equality)
  • Student Space (student mental health charity)
  • Switchboard LGBT+ helpline
  • The Mix (support for under 25s)
  • The Student Room (UK's biggest student community)
  • YoungMinds (mental health charity for young people)
